abstracts.cdata!:
Ratings for the Third Manila Sewerage
            Project (MTSP) for Philippines were as follows: overall
            outcome was moderately satisfactory, the risk to development
            outcome was moderate, and both the Bank and the borrower
            performance were moderately satisfactory. Some important
            project lessons learned were: (1) On Use of Private Land vs.
            Public Land. MTSP experience is that purchase acquisition of
            private land, if available, for the project is more
            transparent, easier and less troublesome, in the long run.
            (2) On Technology Choice. The MTSP experience indicates that
            an assessment of the optimization of the design of the
            facilities and choice of technology is recommended.
            Conventional Activated Sludge process might not be the best
            technology option if the utilization rate remains low for an
            extended period of time (5-10 years after construction).
            Other technology options that may be phased or that are
            modular in design may be more energy efficient in the long run.

repnme.cdata!:
Philippines - Manila Third Sewerage Project
            : restructuring

abstracts.cdata!:
The development objectives of the Manila
            Third Sewerage Project for Philippines are to: (a) increase
            the coverage and effectiveness of sewerage service delivery
            in participating areas of Metro Manila (MM) through an
            integrated approach involving septage management, sewage
            management, and heightened consumer awareness of water
            pollution problems and their solutions; and (b) establish
            the financial and technical viability of new approaches for
            sewage management in MM. The Land Bank of the Philippines
            has changes to the project to make the necessary adjustments
            to account for implementation delays. The key changes in the
            project include: (a) deletion of three subcomponents (Ilaya,
            Manggahan and Tapayan sewage treatment plants (STPs) under
            the Sewage Management Component; (b) the addition of Fort
            Bonifacio (Taguig Northeast STP) as replacement for those
            dropped; (c) revision of targets of outcome and results
            indicators affected by the deletion of STPs; and (d)
            reallocation of loan proceeds among expenditure categories.

display_title.display_title:
Philippines - Manila Third
            Sewerage Project : restructuring (Vol. 2) : Data sheet

repnme.cdata!:
Philippines - Manila Third Sewerage Project
            : restructuring

abstracts.cdata!:
The closing date for the Philippines
            Manila Third Sewerage Project will be extended from June 30,
            2010 until June 30, 2012. The supervision mission conducted
            in April-May 2010 concluded that the overall project
            implementation performance is satisfactory. Two components
            (components two, Septage management and component three,
            institutional strengthening) are proceeding ahead of
            schedule. Despite of the delays in component one, sewage
            management, implementation has progressed significantly in
            the past few months and project objectives continue to be
            achievable. Four sub-projects will be completed within the
            calendar year 2010. Disbursement improved to forty-two
            percent of total loan funds from twenty-seven percent in
            about the same period last year. The construction of the
            Taguig Sewage Treatment Plant (STP), which comprises
            thirty-four percent of total amount of the loan, is
            scheduled to be awarded by September 2010 and expected to be
            completed in June 2012.

repnme.cdata!: Potable water improves life for millions in Manila

abstracts.cdata!:
This Results Profile talks about
            portable water that improves life for millions in Manila.
            Over the past 15 years, Manila’s growing urban population
            has demanded a significant increase in water supply and
            sanitation services and facilities. The local
            concessionaires, the Manila Water Company Inc. (MWCI) and
            Maynilad Water Services Inc. (MWSI) were needed to upgrade
            their piped water supply and sanitation coverage due to
            expanding franchise areas. To address the challenge, the
            International Bank for Reconstruction and Development (IBRD)
            set out to promote greater private sector participation to
            improve the sector. IBRD’s involvement in water concessions
            was based on the rationale that the private sector can play
            an important role in delivering services. MWCI and IBRD
            implemented Manila Second Sewerage Project to improve the
            quality of wastewater and septage management service in
            Manila and expand MWCI’s sewerage and septage management
            program. The Manila Third Sewerage Project enhanced septage
            management, piloted a combined sewer-drainage system
            approach and promoted advocacy campaigns on the negative
            environmental impacts of wastewater. Through capital
            infusion, debt restructuring and infrastructure
            rehabilitation, both concessionaires managed to accelerate
            and enhance supply across their franchise areas. MWCI posted
            a dramatic increase in 24-hour water supply, to 99 percent
            in 2009 from 26 percent in 1997. MWCI’s investment program
            reduced the risk of sicknesses from exposure to sewage
            contamination, which is estimated to have reduced mortality
            by 20 percent. IBRD has supported two utilities in expanding
            affordable and efficient water and sewerage services to
            benefit some 107,000 poor households.

docna.cdata!: Agua potable mejora la vida de millones en Manila

display_title.display_title:
Potable water improves life for
            millions in Manila : Agua potable mejora la vida de millones
